tossups.answer: meaning [or content, or intentionality, or aboutness; accept semantics until mention, prompt on “reference” until mention, prompt on “representation” or other reasonable synonyms; do NOT prompt on or accept “knowledge”]

parts:
Name this author who wrote about the Jacobite rebellion in Waverley and about a knight who marries Rowena
and fights for King Richard the Lionheart in Ivanhoe.

In this novel by Scott, the disinherited Frank Osbaldistone goes to Scotland to track down Rashleigh. The title
Highlander disguises himself as the cattle dealer Campbell and dies saving Frank and his love Diana.

This subseries of Scott’s Waverley novels include The Heart of Midlothian and The Bride of Lammermoor. It
begins with The Black Dwarf, whose introduction claims this collection was edited by Jedediah Cleishbotham.

answers: Carl van Clausewitz [or Carl Philipp Gottfried von Clausewitz]
Napoleon Bonaparte [or Napoleon Bonaparte; Emperor Napoleon I]
parts: Name this student of Scharnhorst who theorized a “remarkable trinity” of primordial violence, chance, and subordination to policy while describing a certain activity.

Clausewitz’s On War was greatly influenced by the successes of the wars fought by this French emperor, who savaged the Prussian army at the Battle of Austerlitz. This person received his final defeat at the Battle of Waterloo.

Clausewitz uses this word to describe the factors distinguishing “real war from war on paper.” The fog of war contributes to this aspect, which encompasses the difficulties a commander faces when trying to direct a conflict.
This goddess, who was first mentioned in the Rig Veda, is a patroness of wisdom and music. She is often portrayed riding a white hamsa, or swan, and holding a stringed instrument.
This warrior goddess was known for using her shape-shifting abilities to kill the buffalo demon Mahishasura.
Saraswati and Durga are celebrated with this type of event. These events may include washing statues and offering water and incense, and this term also applies to multi-day celebrations.
Name this short story in which Clark takes the former music teacher Georgiana to the title event, where she is extremely moved and declares “I don’t want to go!” back to her dull life in Nebraska.
“A Wagner Matinee” is by this author of O Pioneers! and My Antonia.

In another Cather story, a boy by this name runs away to New York, lives expensively until he goes broke, then throws himself under a train. This is the first name of a poet surnamed Dunbar who wrote “We Wear the Mask.”

answers: DEPT [or Distortionless Enhancement by Polarization Transfer]
parts: Name this technique in which compounds are subjected to a strong magnetic field, and each non-equivalent atom corresponds to a different peak. It comes in hydrogen and carbon-13 varieties.
The chemical shifts in H1 and C13 NMR are usually given in these units.

By applying a pulse at 45, 90, and 135 degrees, this experiment often done as part of carbon-13 NMR is used to determine the number of hydrogens attached to a given carbon. It’s not the attached proton test.

John McKnight coined the name for this activity, in which investment is denied to certain neighborhoods because of race. This activity gained its name from the color that “Type D” neighborhoods were drawn in.

This New Deal program has been accused of pursuing redlining against African Americans, but recent research has mostly absolved it. FDR created this agency to refinance loans to prevent the collapse of the housing industry.

The 1968 Fair Housing Act, which attempted to prevent housing discrimination based on race and a number of other factors, was passed under this President, whose “Great Society” established Medicare and Medicaid.
This goddess was abducted by Pluto and ate six pomegranate seeds while she was in the Underworld, causing her mother Ceres to throw the world into winter for half the year.
This goddess of orchards and fruit trees married Vertumnus after he disguised himself as an old woman to get into her garden.
Vertumnus convinced Pomona to love him by telling her the story of this Greek shepherd, who hanged himself on Anaxarete’s doorstep after she rejected him. She subsequently turned into a statue.

After analyzing the sequence, you decide to use this class of enzymes that can make specific cuts in the vector plasmid. However, your lab’s inventory is outdated and you realize you do not actually have BamHI and XbaI.

Your neighboring postdoc takes pity on you and recommends that you try his TOPO AT cloning kit. TOPO cloning works because using this kind of DNA polymerase used in PCR will create a 3’ adenine overhang.
Finally, you decide to use this cloning method developed by Invitrogen. This method involves site specific recombination of attP sites and attB sites to create an “entry clone.”

Name this low-budget horror movie considered one of the worst ever made. It features a lost family getting trapped with a polygamous cult run by “the Master,” who somehow kills people by touching them.

Manos: The Hands of Fate was made infamous by this show. In it, a host and the robots Tom Servo and Crow are trapped on a satellite and forced to watch bad movies until they go insane, but mock the films instead.

This red-haired actress played “third-generation supervillain” Kinga Forrester in the Mystery Science Theater reboot. This founder of Geek and Sundry wrote and starred in The Guild as well as Dr. Horrible’s Sing-Along Blog.

answers: the Encyclopedia or a Systematic Dictionary of the Sciences, Arts, and Crafts [or Encyclopédie, ou dictionnaire raisonné des sciences, des arts et des métiers]
parts: Name this massive eighteenth-century reference work that many credited with developing the ideas of the French Enlightenment.
This philosophe was Diderot’s co-editor on the Encyclopedia. Diderot wrote about this man’s “dream” in a namesake set of dialogues.
This most prolific encyclopedist wrote about 17,000 articles for the Encyclopedia, including those for Democracy, France, Government, the Inquisition, Paris, and Superstition.

answers: Busoni Piano Concerto [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this orchestral work by Rimsky-Korsakov. In the first movement of the piece, the titular Sultana is depicted in an intricate violin solo accompanied by a harp.

This other composer wrote an overture and a song cycle based on the Scheherazade myth. He may be better known for paying homage to his Spanish heritage in Rapsodie Espagnole and Pavane for a Dead Princess.

This lengthy concerto features an offstage male chorus singing the words from Adam Oehlenschlager’s Aladdin in the Cantico final movement. Its tarantella fourth movement is difficult for both the soloist and the orchestra.

answers: The Recognition of Shakuntala [or Abhijñānashākuntala or Abhijñānaśākuntalam]
parts: Name this character, a king whom Durvasa curses into forgetting his wife until she shows him her signet ring, which unfortunately gets eaten by a fish.
Dushyanta appears in this Kalidasa play, named after his wife, whom he does finally remember in the end.
Shakuntala originally lives in the woods studying under Mother Gautami with this occupation, which Siddhartha legendarily left his father’s palace to practice.

answers: Project MKUltra [prompt on answers like “the CIA mind control program”]
Marsh Chapel experiment [accept Good Friday experiment]
parts: In this CIA experiment to study LSD’s powers of persuasion, subjects, including soldiers and mental patients, received LSD. It culminated in a CIA-run brothel drugging its clients in Operation Midnight Climax.
In this experiment by Walter Pahnke, theology students reported experiencing genuine religious experiences after receiving psilocybin.

Psychoactive drugs were given to the inhabitants of one of these places in Concord to see how it affected their recidivism rates. Philip Zimbardo ran a famous Stanford experiment modeling one of these places.
This is the most massive fundamental particle discovered to date and was one of two particles proposed to explain CP violation in kaon decay.
The top quark was discovered at the Tevatron, housed at this scientific facility in Illinois. It is named for a scientist who also names a class of particles contrasted with bosons.

This other particle’s mass can be predicted from the mass of the top quark because it has a Yukawa coupling with the left and right handed top quarks. One method of producing it is gluon fusion mediated by a top quark loop.

answers: Chernobyl disaster [accept obvious equivalents for “disaster” like “accident”]
parts: This worst nuclear disaster in British history occurred due to a build up of Wigner Energy in graphite piles. This event released a bunch of harmful radioactive material, including iodine-131, in Cumberland.

The first permanent repository for used nuclear fuel in the world is being built in this country. Its subordination of its foreign policy to the USSR under the Paasikivi-Kekkonen doctrine was dubbed “this country” -ization.
This 1986 event was the greatest disaster to hit the nuclear power industry, spreading radiation across Eastern Europe. This event was the subject of an oral history by Svetlana Alexievich.

answers: a shower [prompt on answers like “gym bathroom,” “hotel bathroom”]
parts: Name this four-word statement that, in the 1983 Scarface remake, is flashed by a zeppelin passing over Tony Montana’s house. At the end of the remake, Tony dies in a pool underneath a statue inscribed with this statement.
The 1983 version of Scarface was directed by this man. The visual style of this director of Carrie, Blow Out and The Untouchables is characterized by slow zooms and split-screens.

Carrie begins with Carrie experiencing her first period in one of these locations. In Hitchcock’s Psycho, shrieking violins play as Marion Crane is brutally stabbed to death in one of these locations within the Bates Motel.

answers: brilliant [accept My Brilliant Friend or My Brilliant Career]
parts: Name this reclusive Italian author who wrote about her friendship with Lila and her escape from a poor neighborhood in the Neapolitan Novels. She is possibly the translator Anita Raja.

The first of the Neapolitan Novels describes the precocious Lila as “my [this adjective] friend”. A Miles Franklin novel describes the writing career of the independent-minded Sybylla Melvyn with this adjective.

This other modern Italian author wrote about a geographically-encoded labyrinthine library that burns down during the investigations of William of Baskerville and Adso of Melk in The Name of the Rose.

Name this event in which a Chevy containing employees of the Institute for Policy Studies was bombed on Embassy Row. This was the only state-sponsored act of international terrorism to ever occur in Washington D.C.

The assassination of Orlando Letelier was part of Phase III of this program of state terrorism which targeted alleged leftist “terrorists” and repressed citizens in the countries of the Southern Cone of Latin America.

Operation Condor was the brainchild of Manuel Contreras, who led the infamous DINA secret police of this leader. This person became president of Chile after leading a coup to overthrow Salvador Allende.

answers: ocean waves [accept wind waves or wind-generated waves or any answer that indicates waves propagating in water; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify these phenomena, which can be modeled numerically using programs like SWAN and MIKE 21. Their “rogue” type occurs when their height exceeds twice the mean trough to crest height.

Stokes’ criteria for waves to undergo this phenomenon include the crest attaining an angle of 120 degrees and the ratio of the wave height to the wavelength equaling approximately 1/7. Subtypes include surging and collapsing.

This dimensionless number is used to determine whether a breaker is spilling, plunging, surging, or collapsing. It equals the tangent of the bed slope divided by the square root of the wave height over the deep water wavelength.
Name this long-time satirical cartoonist for Punch, who is better known for showing that girl with a bottle that says “Drink Me” in his illustrations for Alice in Wonderland.

Salvador Dali also illustrated a rare edition of Alice in Wonderland. Characteristically, he turned the Mad Hatter’s tea table into a melting one of these objects, which is found covered in ants in The Persistence of Memory.

This British Surrealist showed crocodiles swimming through a background of galaxies in a painting based on the poem “How Doth the Little Crocodile.” She depicted her relationship with Max Ernst in The Inn of the Dawn.
